``At the same time, we ei9:want to ei10:help Kenya prepare to ei12:meet future medical ei36:disasters, regardless of their cause.''
The ei38:bombings on Aug. 7 ei13:killed 259 people, including 12 Americans, and ei55:injured more than 5,500.
The U.S. team includes plastic surgeons with experience in physical reconstruction, and a psychiatrist who ei16:worked in Oklahoma City, where 168 people were ei17:killed in a ei41:bombing in 1995.
The team planned to ei19:leave Nairobi on Thursday for Dar es Salaam.
Besides ei20:meeting the immediate physical and emotional needs of ei43:bombing victims, the United States will ei21:consider ei22:helping ei23:set up a disaster response center in Kenya, Satcher ei24:said.

The U.S. government already has ei30:contributed dlrs 3.2 million in assistance to the two countries.
On Friday, the Kenyan government planned to ei32:pay the first 32 death claims of 100,000 Kenyan shillings (dlrs 1,667) each.

text:
WASHINGTON (AP) --
Preliminary DNA tests ei1:link a missing anti-abortion activist to a strand of hair ei2:found near where a sniper ei3:shot and ei4:killed a Buffalo, N.Y., doctor who ei5:performed abortions, a law enforcement official ei6:said Friday.
The first round of DNA tests on the hair at the FBI Laboratory here ei7:established a high probability it ei8:came from the same person as a hair ei9:found in a New Jersey home where James C. Kopp, a 44-year-old anti-abortion protester, ei10:lived last year, the official ei11:said.
The first DNA tests did not ei12:exclude a match between the two strands.
Kopp has ei13:eluded authorities since they ei14:obtained a warrant for him as a material witness in the Oct. 23 sniper ei15:shooting of Dr. Barnett Slepian, a 52-year-old obstetrician-gynecologist who ei16:performed abortions. The ei17:search for Kopp was recently ei18:extended to Mexico.
Meantime, FBI agents and Metropolitan Police officers ei19:assigned to a joint terrorism task force here ei20:scanned the crowd of anti-abortion protesters at the annual ei21:March for Life on Capitol Hill, because Kopp has been either a ei24:participant in or ei23:arrested at this ei25:march in each of the last three years, according to another law enforcement official,
Both officials ei26:requested ei27:anonymity.
The FBI is ei28:conducting further DNA tests of the hair ei29:found outside Dr. Slepian's home. This more extensive set of tests could ei30:enable officials to ei31:declare an absolute ei32:match between the two hair strands, the first law enforcement official ei33:said.
``Ultimately, we would ei34:need to ei35:have a hair ei36:taken directly from Kopp himself to ei37:establish conclusively the hair from scene ei39:is his,'' the official ei38:added.
The official ei40:said the hair ei41:was in a cap that authorities ei42:found very near the location from which the sniper is ei43:thought to have ei44:fired the rifle bullet that ei45:killed Slepian as he ei46:stood in the kitchen of his home in the Buffalo suburb of Amherst, N.Y.
But The Buffalo News ei47:reported Friday that the hair ei48:was in a packet, with at least two bullets, that was ei49:found ei50:buried in the ground more than 50 feet from a tree where police ei51:believe the sniper ei52:stood and ei53:fired.
Last week, FBI Director Louis Freeh, on an official ei54:visit to Mexico, ei55:asked Mexican authorities to ei56:join the ei57:hunt for Kopp, federal officials have ei58:said.
They ei59:believe Kopp was ei60:driven to Mexico by a female friend after the ei61:shooting, and ei62:have a trail of her credit card receipts ei63:leading to Mexico, the federal officials have ei64:said.
In addition, a Customs Service videotape from a border crossing point ei65:shows the woman's car ei66:returning from Mexico, these officials ei67:said.
Authorities ei68:obtained a material-witness arrest warrant for Kopp after they ei69:said Kopp's car was ei70:spotted in Amherst in the weeks before Slepian was ei71:killed.
Kopp's 1987 Chevrolet Cavalier was ei72:discovered last month at Newark, N.J., International Airport, the FBI ei73:said. The car had ei74:been in the long-term lot for about two weeks, ei75:said Greg Trevor, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

text:
ATLANTA (AP) --
The creator of an anti-abortion Web site ei1:found to be a threat to abortion providers ei2:says a ei3:decision to ei4:shut the site down is just a ``temporary ei5:setback.''
Neal Horsley ei6:said Friday that he would ei7:seek a new Internet service for his ``Nuremburg Files'' site, which ei8:was the focus of a federal court ei9:trial that ei10:led to a $107 million ei11:verdict this week in favor of abortion providers.
Horsley ei12:was not a defendant in the ei13:suit, in which the Portland, Ore., jury ei14:ruled that such sites ei15:constitute threats to abortion providers.
MindSpring, which ei16:provided the Internet space for the site, ei17:closed it Thursday night for ei18:violating ``our appropriate use policies,'' spokesman Serge Clermont ei19:said.
The Web site ei20:included the names and addresses of abortion doctors and ei21:featured ei22:photos of mangled fetuses and ei23:drawings of dripping blood.
Three times, doctors whose names ei24:appeared on the list were ei25:killed, most recently last October when Dr. Barnett Slepian was ei26:gunned down by sniper fire in his home outside Buffalo, N.Y. His name on the Web site was ei27:crossed out that same day.
Pathway Communications, which has ei28:maintained the site, ei29:said in a statement that ``The Nuremberg Files'' was ei30:knocked off-line without notice. The company ei31:said it was ei32:informed Friday that it ei33:violated MindSpring's policy on ``threatening and harassing language.''
Horsley ei34:called the ei36:move a ``temporary ei35:setback.''
``We are presently ei37:searching for a bolder and more principled (Internet service provider) to ei38:host the Nuremburg Files,'' the statement ei39:said.

text:
INDEPENDENCE, MO. (AP)--
Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic today ei1:became full-fledged members of NATO, less than a decade after ei2:exchanging communist rule for democracy and ei3:shedding their Cold War military ties to the Soviet Union.
Secretary of State Madeleine Albright ei4:accepted admission papers from the three countries' foreign ministers, ei5:marking their formal ei6:entry into the 50-year-old alliance. ``Hallelujah,'' Albright ei7:exclaimed.
``Hungary has ei9:come home. We ei10:are back in the family,'' ei11:said Hungarian Foreign Minister Janos Martonyi.
In a touch of symbolism, the ei12:ceremony ei13:took place at the Harry S. Truman Library. It was during the Truman ei15:presidency that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was ei16:founded to ei17:halt the westward ei82:spread of Soviet-led communism.
Ironically, NATO's three newest members just a decade ago ei18:were still under the Soviet umbrella.
Czech Foreign Minister Jan Kavan ei19:said he ei20:was in nearby Kansas City ei21:working with the anti-Soviet undergound in 1968 when Russian troops ei22:swept through Praque in the ei23:occupation of Czechoslovakia.
``It is for me very symbolic that it is precisely here that we today ei24:accept the guarantee that my country never again will ei25:become the powerless victim of foreign invasion,'' Kavan said.
In ei26:looking ahead to even greater ei27:expansion of NATO, Polish Foreign Minister Bronislaw Geremek ei28:said, ``We should ei29:keep the door of the alliance open for those who have ei30:fought for freedom ... Another curtain should never ei31:descend on Europe.''
There were 12 original members of NATO at the time of its ei32:founding. Since 1949, it has been ei33:expanded to include Greece and Turkey in 1952, Germany in 1955 and Spain in 1982. The new additions ei34:bring the total to 19 and many other hopefuls are ei81:waiting in the wings: Slovenia, Romania, Bulgaria, Slovakia, Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia.
Just what NATO will ei35:do with these eager applicants is not clear. The issue is ei36:expected to ei37:dominate a NATO ei38:summit set for Washington in April.
NATO's mission has ei39:changed dramatically since its ei40:founding in 1949, a time when the West ei41:was intent on ei42:halting the westward ei84:spread of Soviet-led communism -- a threat Winston Churchill ei43:warned about in his famous ``Iron Curtain'' speech ei44:delivered on March 5, 1946, at Westminster College in Fulton, Mo., 130 miles east of here.
Now the alliance's mission is more ill-defined. NATO warplanes ei45:helped ei46:end the ei85:war in Bosnia almost four years ago and now are ei47:poised to ei48:intervene in Yugoslavia should peace ei49:efforts in the province of Kosovo ei50:fail.
A decade ago, the military planning of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic was ei51:built around the possibility of a ground assault toward the west. As NATO allies, the goal ei52:is much smaller armies ei53:capable of meeting a variety of contingencies.
The State Department ei54:says the three new members ``ei55:enhance NATO's ability to fulfill its core mission of collective defense, ei56:respond to a range of security challenges and ei57:reduce the possibility of another major conflict in Europe of the kind that has ei58:claimed so many American lives.''
NATO Secretary General Javier Solana ei59:says, ``The ei60:accession of the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland ... is perhaps the clearest ei61:demonstration of the fact that Europe is ei62:growing closer together.''
``ei63:Extending membership to these three democracies ei64:helps to ei65:stabilize a region that historically has been the staging ground for many of the ei66:disasters of this century.''
But many Russians -- and some Americans -- ei67:are wary about the eastward encroachment of NATO. Former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev ei68:says the push east ei69:signifies a ei70:rejection of the common European security system that was ei71:discussed at the ei72:end of the Cold War.
Russian Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov ei73:calls ei74:extending NATO membership into Eastern Europe ``a ei75:movement in the wrong direction.''
``All European states must ei76:cooperate in creating a joint security system,'' he was ei77:quoted as ei78:saying. ``All European states must ei79:work together in the interests of all countries rather than of separate groups.''

text:
AMHERST, N.Y. (AP) --
A rifle ei1:found near the home of a slain abortion doctor may ei2:yield important clues for investigators ei3:trying to ei4:track down the gunman.
Dr. Barnett Slepian was ei5:killed in his kitchen by a sniper's bullet last fall. Investigators ei6:said Friday they ei7:found a rifle ei8:buried near his home in the Buffalo suburb of Amherst.
The gun was ei9:sent to the FBI laboratory in Washington to ei10:determine whether it was ei11:used to ei12:kill Slepian.
``If itei13:'s not too badly rusted, they may be ei14:able to ei15:match the bullet back to the weapon,'' ei16:said Walter Rowe, forensics sciences professor at George Washington University.
The rifle might also ei17:have clothing fibers, fingerprints or a serial number that can be ei18:traced to the buyer, Rowe ei19:said.
ei20:Buried a foot beneath the ground, the weapon was ei21:unearthed during a ei22:search of a heavily wooded, four-acre area Thursday. Investigators did not ei23:say how close the weapon ei24:was to the house.
Anti-abortion protester James Kopp is being ei25:sought as a material witness in the ei26:shooting.
Investigators ei27:said Kopp's car was ei28:seen in the neighborhood in the days before the ei29:slaying. Kopp ei30:vanished after the ei31:shooting, and the car was ei32:found ei33:abandoned at the Newark, N.J., airport in December.
Officials ei34:said DNA test results ei35:showed a likelihood that a strand of hair ei36:discovered behind Slepian's home ei37:came from Kopp.

text:
BUFFALO, N.Y. (AP) --
An abortion foe who ei1:is the subject of an international ei2:manhunt was ei3:charged with murder Thursday in the ei4:slaying of a doctor who was ei5:cut down in his kitchen by a sniper's bullet.
Federal and state arrest warrants were ei6:issued for James C. Kopp, 44, of St. Albans, Vt. His whereabouts ei7:are unknown.
``We ei8:have probable cause to ei9:believe this man, James Kopp, is ei12:responsible for the ei11:death of Dr. Barnett Slepian,'' FBI agent Bernard Tolbert ei13:said.
Investigators have been ei14:searching for Kopp since shortly after the Oct. 23 ei15:slaying. Up until Thursday, however, they had ei16:described him only as a material witness ei17:wanted for ei18:questioning -- not a suspect.
In addition to a state charge of murder, Kopp ei20:faces a federal charge of ei22:violating the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act by ei23:using deadly ei24:force against an abortion doctor. Both charges ei25:carry up to life in prison. The federal charge also ei26:carries a fine of up to $250,000.
The newly filed charges will ei27:intensify the ongoing international ei28:manhunt, Tolbert ei29:said.
In response to the new charges, Canadian officials ei30:confirmed that Kopp ei31:is a suspect in sniper ei32:shootings that ei82:injured abortion doctors in November in Vancouver, British Columbia; Winnipeg, Manitoba; and Hamilton, Ontario.
Investigators would not ei33:divulge the ei34:evidence against Kopp but ei35:said last month's ei36:discovery of a scope-equipped rifle ei37:buried near the Slepian home ei38:represented a major ei39:breakthrough. Slepian, 52, was ei40:shot with a rifle.
Authorities have ei41:said they ei42:believe the weapon may have been ei43:buried in advance of the ei44:shooting, with the killer ei45:digging it up to ei46:fire the shot, then ei47:reburying it and ei48:fleeing.
Kopp also has been ei49:linked, through DNA testing, to a strand of hair ei50:found near where the sniper ei51:fired, law enforcement sources have ei52:said.
ei53:Nicknamed the ``Atomic Dog'' in anti-abortion circles, Kopp had been ei54:arrested in several states since 1990 for ei55:protesting abortion. His car was ei56:spotted in Slepian's suburban Amherst neighborhood in the weeks before the ei57:shooting, and was ei58:found ei59:abandoned at New Jersey's Newark International Airport in December, investigators ei60:said.
Kopp's stepmother, who ei61:married Kopp's father when Kopp ei62:was in his 30s, ei63:said Thursday from her home in Irving, Texas: ``I would ei64:like to ei65:see him ei66:come forward and ei67:clear his name if he's not guilty, and if he's guilty, to ei68:contact a priest and ei69:make his amends with society, ei70:face what he ei71:did.''
Kopp ei72:is now the second anti-abortion activist being ei73:sought by the FBI as a suspect in a fatal ei74:attack.
Eric Rudolph has ei75:been on the run since the January 1998 ei76:bombing of a Birmingham, Ala., abortion clinic that ei77:killed an off-duty police officer and ei78:maimed a nurse. He also is ei79:charged in three Atlanta attacks, including the 1996 Olympic ei80:bombing that ei81:killed one person.

text:
WASHINGTON (AP) --
The FBI ei1:put alleged terrorist mastermind Osama Bin Laden and anti-abortion activist and ei2:accused doctor killer James Charles Kopp on the bureau's list of the Ten Most Wanted fugitives Monday.
FBI Director Louis Freeh ei3:said the U.S. government is ei4:offering a reward of up to $5 million for information that ei5:leads to the ei6:arrest and ei7:conviction of Bin Laden, ei8:indicted as the architect of the twin ei9:bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. The Aug. 7, 1998, ei10:bombings ei11:killed more than 200 people, including 12 Americans. It ei12:is the largest reward the government has ever ei13:offered for a fugitive.
A total of $650,000, meanwhile, is being ei14:offered for information ei15:leading to the ei16:arrest of Kopp, who is ei17:charged with ei18:gunning down Dr. Barnett Slepian last fall in his home in Buffalo, N.Y. Slepian ei19:provided legal ei20:abortions in western New York state.
The standard $50,000 reward for information ei21:leading to a listed fugitive's ei22:capture ei23:comes on top of a $500,000 reward ei24:announced earlier by Attorney General Janet Reno, plus a $100,000 award ei25:offered previously by the FBI.
Reno ei26:said Bin Laden and Kopp ei27:have one thing in common: Each wrongly ei28:believes he is ei29:justified in ei30:using all means possible to ei31:achieve his goal.
They also ei32:have in common locations ei33:unknown to the authorities.
Freeh ei34:said Bin Laden may be ei35:hiding out in Afghanistan, which has ei36:been uncooperative in the ei37:case. Kopp, meanwhile, may have ei38:approached the border with Mexico, but it is ei39:unknown whether he ei40:crossed into that country, ei41:said Freeh.
Kopp ei42:purports to ei43:be a devout Roman Catholic, and the majority of jobs he has ei44:held over the past 20 years have ei47:been related to the anti-abortion movement, the Justice Department ei46:said in a news release.
State Department international security director Dave Carpenter ei48:said that ei49:placing Bin Laden on the most-wanted list ``ei50:underscores the unwavering ei51:commitment'' by the United States ``to ei52:fight terrorism.'' The FBI ei53:continues to ei54:receive threats from individuals and organizations with ties to Bin Laden, Freeh ei55:said.
Carpenter ei56:said the U.S. government's counterterrorism program has ei57:paid out over $6 million in some 20 cases around the world for credible information.
On the FBI list, Bin Laden and Kopp ei58:replace two former Libyan intelligence agents ei59:charged in the Dec. 21, 1988, ei60:bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 that ei97:killed 259 people on the plane and 11 on the ground in Lockerbie, Scotland. The two were ei61:removed from the list after Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi ei62:agreed in April to ei63:hand them over for trial in the Netherlands, a neutral venue. Lamen Khalifa Fhimah and Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi are ei64:charged with murder, conspiracy to ei65:commit murder and ei66:violations of international aviation safety laws.
Bin Laden and Kopp ei67:are the 455th and 456th persons to be ei68:placed on the FBI's most wanted list, which ei69:began in 1950. Since then, 427 fugitives have been ei70:taken into custody or ei71:located, 133 of them as a result of citizen ei72:assistance, the FBI ei73:said.
Six suspects in the Bin Laden investigation are ei74:known to ei75:be in custody in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. Another eight suspects, including Bin Laden, have been ei76:charged but not ei77:apprehended. Another suspect is ei78:awaiting ei79:extradition from Britain. The FBI ei80:says Bin Laden ei81:is the leader of a terrorist organization ei82:known as Al-Aqeda, ``The Base.''
Kopp ei83:wears eyeglasses, ei84:walks with a slight limp, ei85:is 5 feet, 10 inches tall and ei86:weighs 150 to 175 pounds. Slepian was ei87:killed by a single gunshot ei88:fired from a wooded area through a window of his home.
Prior to the Slepian's ei89:shooting, Kopp had ei90:traveled the country and world, authorities ei91:said. He has been ei92:arrested more than a dozen times during abortion ei93:protests in seven states and Italy, but ei94:has no felony convictions.

``Why should it be ei17:delayed? Who is he? He is no one. I am the father.''
Elian was ei18:found Thanksgiving Day ei116:clinging to an inner tube at sea after his mother, stepfather and eight other people ei168:drowned while ei19:trying to ei20:reach Florida by boat.

``The Congress of the United States is ei169:affording Elian Gonzalez what INS and this administration has not, which is his legal right and his right to due process,'' ei37:said Jorge Mas Santos, chairman of the Cuban American National Foundation. ``This ei38:gives him the protection that he will not be ei39:repatriated to Cuba between now and Feb. 10.''

Also Friday, Miami-Dade Mayor Alex Penelas and Miami Mayor Joe Carollo, ei49:accompanied by one of the family's lawyers, ei50:flew to Washington to ei51:appeal directly to Attorney General Janet Reno. Gov. Jeb Bush also ei52:asked President Clinton to ei53:reverse the INS order.

The grandmother of Elian Gonzalez ei1:said she is willing to ei2:go to Miami to ei3:bring the six-year-old boy home to Cuba, while Fidel Castro's point man on U.S. relations ei4:expressed impatience at Washington's ei80:failure to ei5:enforce a ei81:repatriation order.
In a massive ei83:demonstration ei6:demanding Elian's ei84:return, tens of thousands of Cuban women -- hundreds visibly pregnant and others ei7:carrying small children -- ei8:marched along Havana's seaside boulevard on Friday to the U.S. mission, ei9:waving Cuban flags and ei10:chanting ``ei125:Bring back our son!''
Elian's young stepmother, Nelsy, flanked by his two grandmothers, was at the head of the ``ei126:March of the Combatant Mothers,'' ei11:pushing his half-brother in a stroller. Cuban authorities ei12:estimated that 100,000 women ei13:participated in the ei127:march.
The ei86:protest ei14:marked a return to the larger ei88:demonstrations of early December, when hundreds of thousands of people ei15:rallied in some of Cuba's biggest gatherings since the ei90:triumph of the ei91:revolution that ei16:brought President Castro to power 41 years ago.
Elian, the boy at the center of the international ei92:dispute, was ei17:found ei18:clinging to an inner tube Nov. 25 off the coast of Florida after his mother, stepfather and others ei128:died in a ei19:failed ei94:attempt to ei20:reach U.S. shores. He has been staying with relatives in Miami who do not ei23:want to ei24:send him back to Cuba.
The U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service had ei25:ruled that Elian must be ei26:returned to his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, and ei27:set Friday as the deadline for his ei96:repatriation to Cuba.
But this week, Attorney General Janet Reno ei28:lifted the deadline to ei29:give Elian's relatives in Miami a chance to ei30:fight in federal court to ei31:keep the boy with them.
Ricardo Alarcon, president of the National Assembly and Castro's point man on U.S.-Cuban relations, ei32:told The Associated Press that Cuban authorities are frustrated by Reno's ei98:failure to ei34:set a new deadline and the INS's ei99:failure to ei35:enforce its decision.
``No ei101:enforcement ei102:action was ever ei36:announced by the INS,'' he ei37:said.
Alarcon, former Cuban ambassador to the United Nations, ei38:dismissed suggestions by some U.S. politicians and Elian's relatives in Miami that Elian's father ei104:travel from Cardenas, Cuba, to Miami to ei39:pick up the boy. He ei40:said Cuba has not ei41:prohibited Gonzalez from ei42:going to Miami to ei43:retrieve Elian, American attorneys -- and even American officials -- have ei129:counseled against it.

The concern in Cuba always has been that if Gonzalez ei46:goes he will immediately ei47:become ei48:involved in political and legal problems that will ei49:prevent his speedy ei107:return.
Elian's paternal grandmother, Mariela, ei50:told reporters that she was willing to ei51:go to Miami to ei52:retrieve her grandson if it was ei53:assured to her that she could ei54:pick him up and ei108:return immediately to Cuba without ei55:become ei56:embroiled in legal or political problems.

HAMILTON (AP) --
Canadian authorities ei1:issued a nationwide arrest warrant Monday for James Charles Kopp, a U.S. fugitive ei2:on the FBI's most wanted list for an alleged anti-abortion ei3:murder.
Kopp also is ei4:wanted for ei5:questioning in at least two other ei6:shootings of doctors who ei7:performed abortions.

Slepian was ei23:killed by a single gunshot ei24:fired from a wooded area through a window of his home.
Kopp ei25:purports to ei26:be a devout Roman Catholic, and the majority of jobs he has ei27:held over the past 20 years have been ei30:related to the anti-abortion movement, the U.S. Justice Department ei29:said last year. text:
HAVANA (AP) --
Calling the mother of Elian Gonzalez ``an excellent girl,'' President Fidel Castro ei1:said Friday she had been ``practically ei2:kidnapped'' by the boyfriend who ei125:perished along with her on the boat ei3:wreck her 6-year-old son ei4:survived.
Castro's remarks to a ei77:conference of economists were ei5:aimed at those who ei6:say that Elian should remain in the United States because his mother ei126:sacrificed his life to ei8:take her to ``freedom,'' a vision he ei9:called a cliche.
He ei10:placed the blame on Lazaro Rafael Munero, who apparently ei11:organized the ill-fated ei80:journey on which Elian's mother Elisabeth Brotons and 10 other people -- including Munero -- ei127:died.
Castro ei14:called Munero -- who reportedly ei15:drove a taxi and ei16:engaged in unofficial businesses in the Cuban city of Cardenas -- a ``ruffian'' on whom Cuban police had ei128:amassed ''100 pages of reports.''
According to sources ei17:quoted by the Miami Herald, Munero had ei18:fled to Florida in June 1998 and ei19:returned to Cuba later that year, only to be ei129:jailed for several months.
``The mother was practically ei20:kidnapped along with the boy'' to ei21:make the late-November ei83:trip, Castro ei22:said.
The Cuban leader ei23:said Elian had been especially ei24:loved by his parents because the mother had earlier ei25:suffered seven ei84:miscarriages.
Earlier Friday, Cuba's communist government ei26:celebrated the ei85:birth of independence hero Jose Marti on Friday with ei88:rallies ei27:calling for the ei89:return of Elian Gonzalez, the ``boy martyr'' at the center of an international custody ei91:battle.
Tens of thousands of children ei28:flooded Havana's Plaza of the Revolution to ei29:deliver a dual homage to Marti and Elian, the 6-year-old Cuban whose ei93:rescue off Florida's coast two months ago ei30:set off a tug-of-war between relatives living on both sides of the Florida Straits.
Wearing their red Communist Pioneer neckerchiefs, a string of young boys and girls ei32:recited poems they ei33:wrote for Elian, dubbed Cuba's ``boy hero'' and ``symbolic child,'' and for Marti, commonly known on the island as Cuba's ``teacher'' and ``apostle.''
The Communist Party daily Granma ei35:compared Elian with revolutionary icon Ernesto ``Che'' Guevara and ei36:said the boy ``has been ei130:converted forever into a symbol of the crimes and injustices that imperialism is capable of ei37:committing against an innocent.''
The commemorations were similar to those ei38:held here annually for Marti, the revolutionary and poet who ei39:fought for Cuba's independence from Spain in 1898. But this year, children ei40:wore T-shirts ei103:bearing Elian's portrait with their school uniforms.
The commemorations ei41:began early Friday morning, as tens of thousands of Cubans ei42:marched through Havana's streets by torchlight. Similar ei104:events were ei43:held all day in the capital and across the island.
In Old Havana, hundreds of children ei44:marched around the Parque Central ei105:chanting ``We will ei45:save Elian!'' A small group of girls ei46:wore construction paper handcuffs -- an apparent reference to the government's characterization of Elian's retention in the United States as a ``ei110:kidnapping.''
Fidel Castro's government has been ei47:using such traditional political ei111:events -- along with other ei112:rallies almost every day -- to ei48:draw attention to the case of Elian, who was ei49:rescued Nov. 25 while ei50:clinging to an inner tube. His mother and 10 others ei131:died at sea while ei51:trying to ei52:reach the United States.
For the past two months, Elian's father has ei53:demanded that the boy be ei54:returned to him in Cuba, and the U.S. government has ei55:said that father and son should be ei132:reunited.
But Elian's paternal great-uncle in the United States, ei56:backed by the anti-Castro Cuban American National Foundation, is ei57:fighting in the courts to ei58:keep the boy in Miami.
Cuba ei59:kept up its ei114:condemnation of the ei115:handling of Wednesday's ei116:meeting between Elian and his grandmothers at the home of a Roman Catholic nun in Miami Beach, Fla. Sister Jeanne O'Laughlin ei60:said after the ei117:meeting she ei61:thought Elian should stay in the United States.
``First Fruits of the Monstrousness,'' ei63:read the full-page editorial on the front of Friday's edition of the Communist Party daily Granma. It ei64:offered more details and criticisms of the perceived treatment that Elian's grandmothers, Mariela Quintana and Raquel Rodriguez, ei65:received from O'Laughlin, the Miami relatives and other anti-Castro Cubans during the ei120:encounter.
In an ei121:interview with the Spanish language broadcast of CNN, Elian's father also ei66:criticized how the ei123:meeting was ei67:handled. He ei68:repeated charges that his relatives and others in Miami had ei69:offered him money to ei70:stay in the United States with his son.
``They are not ei71:going to ei72:buy me,'' ei73:said Juan Miguel Gonzalez. ``What is important for me is that they ei74:return the boy to me as soon as possible.''

text:
WASHINGTON (AP) --
The Justice Department is ei1:reviewing whether alcohol-related driving ei97:violations or other ei98:actions by Elian Gonzalez' relatives in Miami warrant ei4:moving the 6-year-old boy to a different, temporary custodian.
``That matter is under review,'' Deputy Attorney General Eric Holder ei5:said when ei6:asked Thursday about the ei100:violations. ``We will ei7:look at that, ei8:try to ei9:make some kind of factual determination and then ei149:decide what steps, if any, ei11:need to be ei12:taken.''
In addition, the department is still ei13:considering a ei103:request last week from Elian's father in Cuba, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, to have Elian's temporary custody ei14:shifted from his great-uncle Lazaro Gonzalez to another great-uncle, Manolo Gonzalez. Both great-uncles live in Miami.
Juan Miguel Gonzalez ei16:objected to the media access to Elian that Lazaro Gonzalez's family has ei17:permitted and to the treatment of Elian by psychologists ei18:selected by Lazaro Gonzalez's family.
Meantime, the possibility of a ei107:meeting between Attorney General Janet Reno and Lazaro Gonzalez's family ei19:reemerged Thursday. Reno ei20:agreed to a ei108:meeting earlier this week, only to have Lazaro Gonzalez's family ei21:withdraw the request. But ei110:discussions have been ei22:renewed, a Justice official ei23:said Thursday.
Later Thursday, two of Elian's Miami cousins ei24:sought support on Capitol Hill for legislation that would ei25:help ei26:keep the boy in America. One of them, Marisleysis Gonzalez, ei27:told a news ei113:conference that reports of alcohol-related ei115:violations by relatives should not have bearing on the custody case.
``We're ei29:doing what's in Elian's best interest. My family is a very close family,'' she ei30:said.
Another cousin, Georgina Cid, ei31:said Elian's father had ei32:intended to ei33:flee Cuba himself, but was being ei150:coerced by the Castro government to ei34:stay and ei35:make certain statements.
``He ei36:wanted to reunite with his son -- but not in Cuba,'' Cid ei37:said. She ei38:said she and other family members had ei39:spoken to Elian's father by phone both before and after the mother ei151:perished.
The father's response when ei40:learning that his boy was safe in Miami was ``ei120:take ei121:care of him until I can ei41:go, ei42:meaning ei122:go to the United States,'' Cid ei43:said.
A group of Florida lawmakers ei152:introduced legislation this month to ei44:grant Elian American citizenship, which would ei45:take the ei154:decision about Elian's future away from INS and ei46:give it to a Florida family court. Support for the bill has been ei47:waning.
Reno has already ei48:met with Lazaro Gonzalez's lawyer and a Catholic nun from Miami who ei49:oppose his ei125:return to Cuba, as well as with Elian's two grandmothers from Cuba, who ei50:want him ei51:returned.
In Havana, Elian's father ei52:joined President Fidel Castro on Thursday in a ei53:packed auditorium in what has ei54:become a daily public ei126:rally to ei55:press for the boy's ei127:return. Speaker after speaker ei56:denounced the United States and ei153:extolled the virtues of Cuba's communist ei128:revolution.
A Justice official, who ei57:requested anonymity, ei58:said the department has authority, if necessary, to ei59:shift temporary custody to someone other than Lazaro Gonzalez. The boy was ei60:placed in his care after being ei61:found ei62:clinging to an inner tube in the Atlantic last Thanksgiving ei63:following a boat ei132:wreck that ei64:killed his mother and 10 other people.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service has ei65:ruled in favor of the father's ei134:request that the boy be ei66:returned to him in Cuba, but that ei135:decision was ei67:put on hold while the Miami relatives ei68:battle in federal court to ei69:keep him in this country.
Holder ei70:said that INS ei71:acted appropriately but ``now that we have this new information, we'll have to ei72:look at it, and ei73:see, like I ei74:said, what steps if any are appropriate.''
Florida state records ei76:show Lazaro Gonzalez, 49, was ei77:found guilty of ei78:driving under the influence of alcohol at least twice from 1991 to 1997. Records also ei79:show Lazaro Gonzalez's 62-year-old brother, Delfin Gonzalez, has been ei80:found guilty at least twice of ei81:driving under the influence.
On Wednesday, Ricardo Alarcon, head of Cuba's National Assembly and Castro's key man for U.S.-Cuban relations, ei82:said the ei141:convictions ei83:prove the homes of those uncles are no place for Elian.
``Practically everyone surrounding him either has been, or may be in the future, ei84:joining the prison system in the U.S. That's not the best interest of the child,'' Alarcon ei85:told reporters in Havana. He ei86:said Elian was ``surrounded by two drunks.''
Armando Gutierrez, a spokesman for the Miami relatives, ei87:dismissed the ei143:criticism: ``Elian is surrounded by love.'' Elian's relatives and other Miami supporters ei88:say his mother died to ei89:give him freedom.
The newspaper of Cuba's Communist Party, daily Gramma, ei90:published a letter Thursday from Elian's grandmothers to Reno and Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner Doris Meissner ei91:asking for Elian's ei146:return.
``No material good ei92:exists that can ei93:compete with the value of the family, and it is humiliating for us that people are still ei94:questioning our love and the future that awaits Elian at his home,'' ei95:said a Spanish version of the letter, ei96:dated Feb. 4.

text:
HAVANA (AP ) --
Elian Gonzalez's father ei1:said in a letter ei2:published Wednesday that he ei3:wants Cuban diplomats based in Washington to ei5:meet with his 6-year-old son in Miami and ei54:check on his condition.
``We are worried not only about his prolonged ei55:kidnapping,'' Juan Miguel Gonzalez ei6:wrote in a letter ei7:published on the front page of the Communist Party daily Granma. ``We ei8:lack direct information about the concrete conditions to which he is ei9:subjected in his daily life.''
There was no immediate ei56:response from the U.S. government to the ei57:request. It was likely to be ei10:opposed by Elian's Miami relatives, who are ei11:fighting to ei12:keep the boy in the United States and who have ei13:said they ei14:think Gonzalez is being controlled by Fidel Castro's government.
Gonzalez also ei16:wrote to Attorney General Janet Reno earlier this week,ei17:demanding that Elian be ei18:returned to him and ei19:saying he does not ei77:recognize the courts ei74:hearing the custody ei59:battle. The Justice Department ei21:said it was ei22:reviewing that letter.
Gonzalez's second letter to Reno in two weeks was ei23:published in Granma on Tuesday.
``I formally ei24:object to the legal ei60:moves made or being made by those who are arbitrarily ei27:retaining Elian,'' Gonzalez ei28:said in the letter, ei29:dated Monday.
In the letter, Gonzalez ei30:said he does not ei75:recognize the jurisdiction of theU.S. court system, which is weighing an ei62:attempt by Elian's Miami relatives to ei31:block his ei63:return to Cuba.
Elian has been the focus of an international custody ei65:battle since he was ei32:found on an inner tube off the Florida coast on Nov. 25. The boy's mother and 10 other people died when their boat ei33:sank on the way from Cuba to the UnitedStates.
Elian is staying with his paternal great-uncle Lazaro Gonzalez, who is ei35:fighting to ei36:keep the boy with him in the United States. ''More important than the doctors are those 12 children'' from Elian's first-grade class in Cuba, Castro ei48:said.

Also on the list was National Assembly President Ricardo Alarcon, who has ei50:served as adviser to Gonzalez over the past four months and a senior member of Cuba's communist leadership.
Ultimately, U.S. officials ei51:approved and ei52:delivered six visas, for the four family members, a pediatrician and Elian's teacher from his year in kindergarten.

MIAMI (AP) --
After a weekend of bitter accusations ei1:lobbed by both sides of the Elian Gonzalez custody ei97:battle, attention ei2:returned today to the federal judges ei141:deciding a key point in the international case.
The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta has been ei3:asked by the U.S. government to ei4:suspend a ei99:ruling by one of its judges that ei5:prevents the ei100:removal of Elian from the country.
Such a ei101:decision would ei6:allow the U.S. government to ei7:push for the 6-year-old boy's swift ei102:reunion in Washington with his ei103:waiting father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, who ei8:wants to ei9:return to Cuba. He has ei10:said he will ei11:wait out appeals by the Miami relatives ei12:seeking an asylum ei105:hearing for Elian before the same court -- but only if he has custody of his son.
There was ei13:growing apprehension outside the Little Havana home where the boy has ei14:lived with his great-uncle for nearly five months.
''The feeling is the Clinton administration might ei15:send federal agents to ei16:pull him out of here,'' ei17:said Sergio Navarro, a 39-year-old Miami businessman who ei18:spent part of Sunday night with ei19:chanting protesters.
Elian's relatives have ei20:cared for him since November, when he was ei21:found ei22:clinging to an inner tube in the Florida Straits. His mother and 10 other people ei23:fleeing Cuba ei142:drowned when their boat ei24:sank.
The Clinton administration has ei25:pushed for the boy's ei112:return to his father, ei113:ruling only he can ei26:speak for his son on immigration matters. The boy's Miami relatives ei27:say he will have a better life here and have ei28:attempted to portray Juan Miguel Gonzalez as a pawn of Fidel Castro.
The Justice Department ei29:wants the appeals court to ei30:suspend the temporary injunction ei31:issued Thursday and also ei118:order Elian's great-uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, to ei32:release the boy. The relatives ei33:want the court to ei34:let them ei35:meet with Elian's father without being ei36:required to ei37:surrender the boy.
The court watch ei38:comes after one of the most bitter charges yet in the custody ei122:battle.
Juan Miguel Gonzalez ei39:lashed out at his Miami relatives Sunday night, ei40:accusing them of ''child abuse'' for ei41:turning his son against him. He ei42:said they have ei43:manipulated his son to ei44:believe that his mother still may ei45:show up someday -- in this country.
''This is child abuse and mistreatment, what they're ei46:doing to this boy,'' Gonzalez ei47:said on CBS's ''60 Minutes.'' ''The way they're ei48:abusing him, ei49:turning him against his father ... he's ei50:suffering more here amongst them than he ei51:suffered in the sea.''
Gonzalez ei52:said he didn't believe a much-publicized video taped at the relatives' home in which his son ei55:said he didn't ei56:want to ei57:go. He has ei58:spoken with Elian at least three times since he ei59:arrived in the United States on April 6, and he ei60:insisted his son ei61:wants to ei62:return to Cuba.
''He's ei63:told me so,'' Gonzalez ei64:said. The Miami relatives are ``ei65:putting a bunch of toys in front of a 6-year-old. He cannot ei143:decide for himself. The one that ei144:decides for him is me, his father.''
Elian's Miami relatives have ei66:filed affidavits ei67:alleging Gonzalez ei145:abused his former wife and his 6-year-old son, a charge Gonzalez ei68:denied. During the time of the ei128:broadcast on Sunday, family members and Elian were outside the home of Lazaro Gonzalez and did not publicly ei69:comment after the ei129:show.
Protesters, however, ei70:dismissed Juan Miguel's comments as either selfish or the words of Fidel Castro.
''Fidel Castro is ei71:claiming the son, not him,'' ei72:said Olga Coto, 56, of Miami. ''He's being ei73:manipulated totally by Fidel Castro. He's not ei74:telling the truth.''
Many ei75:worried their efforts to ei76:keep the boy in Miami would ei77:fail today, the 39th ei132:anniversary of the Bay of Pigs ei133:fiasco, an aborted ei134:invasion of Cuba by CIA-trained exiles that ei79:left much bitterness among the Cuban-American community.
''We were ei146:betrayed by the government, by (President) Kennedy, and if they ei80:turned the child back over, it will be a second ei136:betrayal,'' ei81:said Josefa Gonzalez, who ei82:left Cuba in 1962 when she was 4.
Earlier Sunday, protesters ei83:prayed for divine help as Easter week ei84:began, ei85:waving palm fronds and posters of the Cuban boy and Jesus. Priests ei86:joined the crowd to ei87:offer a religious service.
''There are many people who ei88:tell us that we should ei89:give up this ei138:fight,'' ei90:said Martin Anorga, an evangelical pastor. ''But we will ei91:follow in the path that the Lord has ei92:shown us, despite those who ei93:want to ei94:get in our way.''

text:
WASHINGTON _
The ei83:bombings at the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania have ei1:frightened away travelers from East Africa just as Kenya was hoping for an end to a years-old slump in foreign tourism, and as Tanzania was finally ei3:beginning to ei137:reap the benefits from a major investment in the travel industry.
Tour operators who specialize in travel in Kenya and Tanzania, which boast some of Africa's best game parks and sunniest beaches, ei6:say there have been no mass ei91:cancellations as a result of the Aug. 7 Embassy ei92:bombings in Nairobi, the Kenyan capital, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, which ei7:left more than 250 people dead.
But they ei8:report a number of worried ei138:calls from prospective travelers, many of them alarmed by the possibility of more terrorist ei93:attacks in the region. ``People have been ei12:calling, and we've been ei139:reassuring them that we don't ei14:see further problems,'' ei15:said Mary Mkimbo, a spokeswoman in New York for the Kenya Tourist Office.
The State Department, which does not ei16:want to ei17:see Kenya and Tanzania punished economically as a result of terrorist ei94:attacks that were clearly ei19:targeted at the United States, has ei20:lifted dire travel warnings ei21:issued just the ei97:bombings that ei22:urged Americans to stay away from the two countries. New public announcements ei24:put out on Aug. 13 suggest only that Americans ``exercise caution'' when ei26:visiting Kenya and Tanzania.
Embassy employees in both cities have ei27:gone back to ei28:work, although in new locations. The bombed-out Embassy in Nairobi is ei30:expected to be ei31:demolished after the FBI has ei32:finished ei33:gathering evidence. The embassy in Dar es Salaam ei34:suffered less damage from the ei102:blast, although it, too, may have to be ei35:razed. For now, the State Department ei36:says, Embassy employees can ei37:offer only emergency consular service.
Foreign visitors to Nairobi and Dar es Salaam since the ei104:bombings have noted a reassuringly heavy presence of both police and soldiers on the streets of the two capitals. Crew-cut FBI agents fill many of the luxury hotels in the two cities.
Western diplomats and intelligence officials ei40:say there is no reason to ei41:believe that terrorists affiliated with Osama bin Laden, the exiled Saudi millionaire who is ei44:accused of ei45:organizing the Embassy ei108:bombings, plan to ei46:strike again soon in either country.
Still, the televised images of the charred hulks of the American Embassy buildings will likely haunt the travel industry in East Africa for years. ``The tourism industry is very sensitive to the news media,'' ei47:said Ms. Mkimbo. ``We do ei49:expect a little downward movement in the industry.''
The tourism industry in Kenya has been troubled for years _ in part because of the ei114:opening of new safari destinations in South Africa, in part because of Nairobi's well-deserved reputation for street crime. Tourism industry revenues reportedly ei50:dropped to $300 million last year, down from $450 million the year before.
The government has ei51:responded to the slump with a series of ei118:actions to ei141:lure tourists back, including a marked improvement in the service of Kenya Airways, the national airline, which has ei54:gone into partnership with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. The ei120:bombing will doubtless ei55:set back those efforts.
Tourism has never been so well-developed an industry in neighboring Tanzania, which is home to Mt. Kilimanjaro, the magnificent wildlife of Serengeti National Park and the exotic island of Zanzibar.
But the lack of infrastructure has ei57:worked to Tanzania's advantage in recent years given the dramatic growth in the number of adventure travelers who are willing, even eager to ei59:go without the five-star safari resorts that Kenya offers. The number of visitors to Tanzania ei61:jumped from fewer than 100,000 in 1980 to more than 300,000 last year, prompting the government to ei63:improve roads needed for safari tours.
``Tanzania has just been underdeveloped for years, and they're ei64:beginning to ei65:develop it now,'' ei66:said Jalal Ebrahim, president of Safaricentre International, a tour operator in Manhattan Beach, Calif. ``There were fewer people in the parks in Tanzania, and that's what attracted visitors. It was more pristine.''
Ebrahim, whose company has been ei67:sending American travelers on East African safaris for 13 years, ei68:said that his company had ei69:received only one ei131:cancellation as a result of the embassy ei132:bombings _ and that he did not ei70:expect many more.
``We had one ei133:cancellation from a couple who decided they were just going to ei72:wait and ei73:see what happened,'' he ei75:said. ``Our clients are adventure travelers and most of them are very savvy. They ei76:read a lot, they stay on top of world events.'' They ei78:understand, he ei79:said, that increasingly terrorism knows no borders.
The U.S. Embassy in Nairobi is now operating out of the offices of the Agency for International Development on The Crescent, in the neighborhood of Nairobi known as the Parklands; (254-2) 751-613. The Embassy in Dar es Salaam is at 285 Toure Drive; (255-51) 666-015.

text:
The New York Times ei1:said in an editorial on Monday, Oct. 26:
The ei2:murder of Dr. Barnett Slepian is the latest depraved ei3:assault on the small number of courageous physicians who still ei4:risk their safety to ei5:perform legal abortions in this country. Slepian ei6:was one of only three doctors who ei7:performed abortions in the Buffalo, N.Y., area, and harassment and threats against him by anti-abortion groups had ei8:become routine over the past decade. He ei9:persevered through courage and a belief in the right of his patients to ei10:choose whether to ei11:bear a child.
But a principled ei12:commitment to ei13:provide a constitutionally protected ei14:service could not ei15:stop the assassin's bullet that ei16:tore through his kitchen window and into his back Friday night. His death ei17:shows again how tentative the right to abortion has ei18:become in the face of ei19:terrorism by anti-choice fanatics.
Their repeated ei20:acts of terrorism must be ei21:met with the severest possible ei22:crackdown by law-enforcement authorities. If an armed police officer has to be ei23:stationed outside every abortion provider's home and office, 24 hours a day, let it be ei24:done. This is an ei25:assault not only on individual doctors but on the rights and liberties of all Americans.
Last week the FBI ei26:joined Canadian authorities to ei27:investigate a series of unsolved sniper ei28:shootings of doctors in Canada and western New York dating to 1994. In January, a week after the 25th ei29:anniversary of the Roe vs. Wade Supreme Court decision, a clinic ei31:bombing in Birmingham, Ala., ei32:killed a security guard and severely ei33:wounded a nurse.
Since 1993, three doctors, including Slepian, three clinic employees and a clinic escort have been ei34:murdered. There have ei35:been more than a dozen attempted ei36:murders of abortion providers in the last five years. ei37:Arson and ei38:bombings at clinics have ei39:become so common that many no longer ei40:make the national news.
It ei41:is bad enough that conservatives in Congress and in state legislatures are ei42:working to ei43:dismantle reproductive rights by ei44:banning certain ei45:procedures, such as so-called partial birth abortion, and by ei46:requiring waiting ei47:periods and parental ei48:consent before an abortion can be ei49:obtained. But those restrictions are at least ei50:imposed by the normal give and take of political and judicial ei51:struggle in a democracy.
What ei52:is outrageous is the ei53:attempt to ei54:shut down abortions by illegal means _ by ei55:shooting the doctors or ei56:bombing the clinics or ei57:harassing the women ei58:seeking to ei59:exercise their constitutional right. Some anti-abortion groups, to their credit, have ei60:denounced the ei61:bombings and ei62:shootings, but others ei63:seem reluctant to ei64:issue the strong ei65:condemnations that are ei66:warranted.
Indeed, one particularly virulent anti-abortion Web site ei67:lists the names of doctors it ei68:says ei69:perform abortions, or ``crimes against humanity,'' with a code ei70:indicating whether they are ``ei71:working,'' ``ei72:wounded'' or a ``ei73:fatality.'' Such incendiary ei74:rhetoric, and frequent ei75:accusations by some anti-abortionists that abortion providers are ei76:committing murder, can only ei77:fuel more terrorism.
The ei78:increase of anti-choice laws and ongoing ei79:campaigns of harassment by protest groups, even short of murder, have ei80:worked to ei81:make abortions harder to ei82:obtain. More than 80 percent of counties in this country ei83:have no abortion provider. In 45 states, the number of doctors who ei84:performed abortions ei85:declined between 1982 and 1992.
Slepian ei86:was among those who ei87:took a stand against ei88:restricting reproductive freedom and ei89:paid with his life. Unless these brave doctors are better ei90:protected, fewer doctors in the next generation will be ei91:willing to ei92:place themselves and their families in such danger. That is what the terrorists ei93:want. They must not be ei94:allowed to ei95:succeed.

text:
Additional details of the ei1:slaying ei2:emerged on Sunday. Slepian's lawyer, Glenn Edward Murray, ei4:said the sniper's bullet ei5:entered through a partially draped kitchen window, ei6:hit Slepian in the back and ei7:exited through his chest. The doctor's wife and one of his sons ei8:were in the kitchen when the shooting ei9:occurred, Murray ei10:said.
The bullet ei11:bounced off a cabinet and ei12:ricocheted into the living room, where the doctor's three other children were ei13:watching television, Murray ei14:said. Slepian's wife and one son ei15:tried to ei16:revive him. Just over an hour later, he was ei17:declared dead at nearby Millard Fillmore Suburban Hospital.
For the most part, people on both sides of the abortion issue ei18:expressed outrage at the ei19:shooting. But one abortion opponent, the Rev. Donald Spitz, the founder of Pro-Life Virginia, ei20:described Slepian's killer as a ``hero'' for ei21:ending the physician's ``bloodthirsty ei22:practice.''
``We as Christians ei23:have a responsibility to ei24:protect the innocent from being ei25:murdered,'' Spitz ei26:said in a statement ei27:released to The Associated Press, ``the same way we would ei28:want someone to ei29:protect us. Whoever ei30:shot the shot ei31:protected the children.''
Most other opponents of abortion, however, ei32:condemned the ei33:shooting and abortion.
In his Sunday Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York, Cardinal John O'Connor ei34:called the murder wrong but he ei35:urged those angered by the ei37:slaying to ei38:be equally angered by abortions. ``He ei41:called on many of the same people to ei42:express outrage at partial birth abortion, which he ei43:called the equivalent of infanticide,'' Joseph Zwilling, a spokesman for the Archdiocese of New York, ei44:said of the cardinal's sermon.
Religious leaders in Buffalo also ei45:condemned the ei46:shooting. Bishop Henry Mansell of the Archdiocese of Buffalo ei47:said it ei48:was ``an act of madness,'' but he went on to ei50:defend the Church's opposition to abortion as ``respecting of human life in all its forms, especially the most vulnerable.''
Susan Dudley, deputy director of the National Abortion Federation, ei51:assailed the remarks and ei52:called on anti-abortion groups to ei53:shift their tactics. She ei54:said the rhetoric of the anti-abortion movement has ei55:helped ei56:lead to violent ei57:attacks against abortion providers.
``I ei58:think that when pro-life organizations ei59:try to ei60:distinguish between themselves and these incidents they are at best ei62:being disingenuous,'' she ei63:said. ``They are the ones who ei65:call these doctors murderers.''
In Amherst, residents who ei66:said they ei67:opposed abortion ei68:decried the ei69:attack and ei70:said they ei71:hoped the perpetrator was ei72:caught.
Men ei73:smoking cigars and ei74:drinking beer with friends after ei75:shooting skeet at the Buffalo Shooting Club in Amherst ei76:said their feelings about abortion ei78:were mixed, but they uniformly ei79:denounced the ei80:killing of Slepian.
Many residents ei81:said abortion had gradually ei82:dwindled as a local issue since Operation Rescue, an anti-abortion group, ei83:started a series of largely unsuccessful ``Spring of Life'' ei84:demonstrations in 1992 ei85:intended to ei86:shut down abortion clinics and ei87:harass local doctors, including Slepian.
Little of the vitriol that the issue ei88:aroused in the late 1980s and early 1990s ei89:remains, residents ei90:said, and many of the local religious leaders who ei91:led the 1992 ei92:protests have ei93:moved.
``The only people that are ei94:left ei95:are the hard-core, fanatical people,'' ei96:said Larry Finkelstien, a high school teacher who ei97:works as an escort at abortion clinics. ``Everyone else has ei98:gone away.''

text:
The ei1:killing of Dr. Barnett Slepian, a gynecologist in Buffalo who ei2:performed abortions, has ei3:become a factor in at least two campaigns in New York, ei4:say political consultants and some campaign advisers.
In the ei5:race for attorney general, the Democratic candidate, Eliot Spitzer, who ei6:favors abortion rights, has ei7:moved quickly to ei8:make the anti-abortion position of his opponent, Attorney General Dennis Vacco, a central issue in the campaign.
And in the tight ei9:race for U.S. Senate, while the Democrat, Charles Schumer, another abortion-rights supporter, has not ei10:raised Slepian's death himself, his aides ei11:say it ei12:puts a new emphasis on the issue.
Slepian was ei13:shot in the back on Friday night as he ei14:stood in his kitchen. No suspects have been ei15:identified. Even before the ei16:killing, Schumer was ei17:tyring to ei18:draw more attention to the anti-abortion record of his opponent, Senator Alfonse D'Amato, a Republican who is also ei19:running on the Right to Life Party line.
In a New York Times/CBS News poll ei20:completed on Saturday, 69 percent of those polled ei21:said they did not ei22:know D'Amato's position on abortion, and only 19 percent ei23:knew that he ei24:opposed abortion rights.
Now events are ei25:doing the ei26:work for Schumer. Slepian's death ei27:was among the first topics ei28:raised in Saturday night's ei29:debate between the two men, and it was instantly ei30:followed by a question to D'Amato on whether he ei31:opposed first-trimester abortions for adult women.
On Tuesday, the National Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League ei32:plans to ei33:hold a news ei34:conference to ei35:screen a television advertisement _ ei36:made last week, before Slepian ei37:died _ featuring Emily Lyons, a nurse who was badly ei38:wounded earlier this year in the ei39:bombing of an abortion clinic in Alabama.
The advertisement, ei40:said Kelli Conlin, the executive director of the New York State affiliate of Naral, is ei41:intended to ei42:spotlight D'Amato's vote against the 1994 Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances ei43:Act, which Schumer ei44:sponsored. The measure ei45:made it a Federal crime to ei46:attack or ei47:blockade an abortion clinic. Now, Ms. Conlin ei48:said, it will ei49:have new resonance, and the organization is ei50:considering ei51:buying more air time.
``It's incredibly sincere and powerful and it would have ei52:been regardless,'' she ei53:said. ``But sensitivities ei54:are so heightened from the ei55:shooting in western New York that it's even more powerful.''
David Eichenbaum, a Democratic political consultant who is not ei56:working for anyone in this year's campaign, ei57:said abortion ``ei58:is no longer the driving issue it once ei59:was, at least on the pro-choice side.''
But, Eichenbaum ei60:said: ``Sometimes an ei61:incident like this will do more to ei62:energize those who are pro-choice who otherwise might not ei63:consider that as an important an issue to ei64:go to the polls over. It ei65:brings it home.''
D'Amato's aides would not ei66:comment about the political ramifications of the ei67:slaying, and Schumer's aides would not ei68:talk about whether they ei69:planned to ei70:refer to it in any advertisements, or whether the candidate ei71:planned to ei72:use it on the campaign trail.
``Both Senator D'Amato and Chuck Schumer ei73:agree this ei74:was a horrific crime and a horrible tragedy,'' ei75:said Josh Isay, Schumer's campaign manager.
But, Isay ei76:added, ``it ei77:heightens the abortion issue.''
Steven Goldstein, the campaign spokesman for Spitzer, ei78:was less reticent. ``Eliot is ei79:going to ei80:make a huge priority of this,'' Goldstein ei81:said. ``ei82:Stopping clinic ei83:violence is ei84:going to ei85:be a major theme of our campaign from now to Election Day.''
In Sunday's ei86:debate against Vacco, Spitzer ei87:attacked him for ei88:failing to ei89:enforce a court ei90:order in 1992 against anti-abortion protesters who had ei91:blocked the entrance to a clinic. It ei92:was the same clinic where Slepian ei93:worked.
A federal judge ei94:removed Vacco, then the U.S. attorney for western New York, from the case. He was ei95:replaced with two special prosecutors. Spitzer also ei96:criticized Vacco for ei97:dismantling the Office of Reproductive Rights, which ei98:investigated threats and crimes against abortion clinics, when he ei99:became attorney general.
On Monday, Spitzer ei100:called for Vacco to ei101:revive that unit immediately, ei102:vowing that he would ei103:do so on his first day in office if ei104:elected.
Goldstein, who ei105:said it ei106:was ``thoroughly, thoroughly possible'' that the issue would ei107:surface in Spitzer's advertisements, ei108:defended the use of the issue by ei109:noting that the attorney general ei110:has direct impact on the issue of clinic access.
Vacco's campaign manager, Matt Behrmann, ei111:said in a statement that Spitzer had ``ei113:sunk to a new and despicable low by ei114:attempting to ei115:capitalize on the ei117:murder of a physician in order to ei116:garner votes.''
``It's possible that New York politics has never ei118:seen anything as crass as Eliot Spitzer's ei119:willingness to ei120:exploit the unfortunate ei121:murder of Slepian as a steppingstone for his own political ambitions,'' Berhrmann ei122:said.
Several consultants ei123:agreed that there might ei124:be political hay to be ei125:made in Slepian's death but that it ei126:had to be done carefully.
``ei127:Trying to ei128:score political points from a ei129:homicide can ei130:have a backlash,'' ei131:said Maureen Connelly, a media consultant not ei132:working for any candidate in next week's ei133:election.

text:
The antiabortion activist ei1:wanted for ei2:questioning in last month's shooting ei3:death of a doctor in a Buffalo suburb may have ei4:fled to Mexico, according to a newspaper report.
James Charles Kopp, 44, of Vermont, was ei5:seen in the car of a female associate ei6:crossing the US border days after a sniper ei7:killed Dr. Barnett Slepian in his kitchen, the Buffalo News ei8:reported Friday.
Kopp has ei9:been the subject of a manhunt following reports that he was ei10:spotted in a vehicle near the scene of the Oct. 23 ei11:slaying of Slepian, 52, an obstetrician who also ei12:performed abortions. The FBI ei13:says Kopp is ei14:wanted as a material witness in the case.
Friday, an FBI official ei15:said authorities are ei16:pursuing more than 400 tips but have not ei17:pinned down Kopp's whereabouts.
``In all candor, the FBI does not ei18:know where James Kopp ei19:is _ period,'' ei20:said Paul Moskal, a spokesman for the bureau's Buffalo office. ``He's as likely to ei21:be in Boston, Massachusetts, as in Buffalo, New York.''
Authorities ei22:want to ei23:question the unidentified woman who allegedly ei24:traveled with Kopp, according to an investigator ei25:quoted by the newspaper.
``She may have ei26:been with Kopp sometime after the ei27:murder,'' the investigator ei28:said. ``Kopp may ei29:be in Mexico. He may have even ei30:traveled further into Central America or South America.''
A task force of US and Canadian officials is ei31:investigating the similarities between the ei32:attack on Slepian and four ei38:others on abortion providers in Canada and upstate New York in the past four years.
The US Justice Department is ei33:offering a $500,000 reward for information ei34:leading to the ei35:arrest and ei36:conviction of those responsible for Slepian's ei37:slaying.

text:
The FBI has ei1:interviewed and ei2:released one of two men who were ei3:sought last week for ei4:questioning in connection with the sniper ei5:slaying of a doctor in the Buffalo, N.Y., area who ei6:performed abortions.
The two men, Ronald Stauber and Michael Gingrich, were ei7:named Thursday in a bulletin ei8:sent by the FBI office in Cleveland to police departments across the country. The men were not ei9:termed suspects, and FBI officials on Saturday ei10:played down the likelihood that either was ei11:involved in the Oct. 23 ei12:killing of the doctor, Barnett Slepian.
``We are ei13:doing dozens if not hundreds of ei14:interviews a day,'' ei15:said Paul Moskal, a spokesman for the FBI office in Buffalo. ``I ei16:know of no information that would ei17:treat these two differently or would ei18:put them in any other category from the hundreds of leads we're ei19:investigating on a daily basis.''
Moskal ei20:said one of the two men _ he ei21:said he did not ei22:know which one _ had been ei23:located, ei24:interviewed and ei25:released. In its Friday issue, The Hamilton (Ontario) Spectator ei26:quoted an officer in the Amherst, N.Y., Police Department as ei27:saying that the FBI. bulletin had ei28:indicated possible ei29:links between the two men and James Charles Kopp, an abortion opponent who is being ei30:sought as a material witness in the case. Amherst police officials ei31:declined to ei32:comment Saturday.
Slepian, 52, an obstetrician and gynecologist, was ei33:shot through the kitchen window of his home in Amherst shortly after he and his wife ei34:returned home from synagogue on the night of Friday, Oct. 23. He ei35:was one of three doctors who ei36:performed abortions in the Buffalo area. Investigators in Canada and the United States are also ei37:looking into four other sniper ei38:attacks on doctors who ei39:performed abortions in Canada and western New York.
Moskal ei40:said the two men apparently ei41:showed up at Slepian's house the day after his ei42:death. They were ei43:trying to ei44:attend a prayer vigil for Slepian but had been ei45:sent to his house by mistake, and a police officer on duty ei46:took their names, Moskal ei47:said. ``They were being ei48:sought for ei49:interviews just because they ei50:were literally in the area after the ei51:homicide,'' he ei52:said.
FBI officials ei53:said they ei54:were not certain whether Stauber or Gingrich had been ei55:involved in antiabortion activities. The two men are ei56:believed to ei57:live in the Cleveland area.
Inspector Keith MacCaskill of the Winnipeg Police Service, a Canadian member of a law-enforcement task force ei58:investigating all five of the ei59:shootings, ei60:said he had never ei61:heard of the men.
Moskal ei62:emphasized that no one has been ei63:named as a suspect in Slepian's ei64:death. ``Just the fact that we are ei65:interviewing anyone doesn't ei66:make them a subject or a suspect in this,'' he ei67:said.

text:
INDEPENDENCE, Mo. _ The North Atlantic Treaty Organization ei1:embraced three of its former rivals, the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland on Friday, formally ei2:ending the Soviet ei3:domination of those nations that ei4:began after World ei5:War II and ei6:opening a new path for the military alliance.
In a ei7:ceremony tinged with the personal and the emotional at the Truman Presidential Library here, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright ei8:watched the foreign ministers of the three countries ei9:sign the documents of accession to the alliance, ei10:signed them herself and then ei11:held them aloft like a victory trophy.
Albright, who was ei12:born in Prague and ei13:fled just after the Communist ei14:takeover in 1948, ei15:made no secret of her joy at her homeland and its neighbors ei16:joining the alliance after a six year trans-Atlantic diplomatic ei17:process ei18:led by the Clinton administration.
``To ei20:quote an old Central European expression, `Hallelujah,''' she ei19:said.
In Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, the moment was ei21:marked by small-scale public ei22:celebrations. In Warsaw, Poland, after dark, as fireworks ei23:lit the sky, the Polish flag and the flag of NATO were ei24:raised side by side near the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Pilsudski Square
In Hungary, NATO members' flags were ei25:raised outside the Defense Ministry. And in Prague, Czech Republic, President Vaclav Havel ei26:said in a ei27:statement, ``Never have we ei28:been part of such a broad, solid and binding security alliance which at the same time ei29:respects in its essence the ei30:sovereignty and ei31:will of our nation.''
The ei32:enlargement of NATO from 16 members to 19 has ei33:been one of the administration's foremost foreign policy goals, one that ei34:grew out of a ei35:desire, its proponents ei36:said, to ei37:cement the democratic ei39:gains made in the former Warsaw Pact countries after the ei38:collapse of communism 10 years ago.
But the policy also ei40:faced critics, who ei41:argued that ei42:welcoming these three new countries would ei43:draw a new line across Europe and ei44:antagonize the Russians. As of Friday, the border between Western Europe and the former Soviet Union ei45:moved to the eastern border of Poland.
In her ei46:speech, in the small auditorium where dignitaries from the three countries ei47:sat and the three foreign ministers ei48:flanked her on the stage, Albright ei49:countered that NATO would now ei50:do ``for Europe's East what NATO has already ei51:helped to ei52:do for Europe's West. Steadily and systematically, we will ei53:continue ei54:erasing _ without ei55:replacing _ the line ei56:drawn in Europe by Stalin's bloody boot.''
Albright also ei59:used her ei60:speech to ei61:articulate a forward-looking vision for NATO, which will ei62:celebrate its 50th anniversary in Washington next month, and to ei63:defend NATO's potential ei64:involvement in Kosovo.
In the ei66:aftermath of the Cold War, she ei65:said, NATO must be ei67:ready to ei68:face ``an aggressive regime, a rampaging faction, or a terrorist group. And we ei70:know that if, past is prologue, we ei71:face a future in which weapons will ei72:be more destructive at longer distances than ever before.''
The NATO ei73:summit, she ei74:said, would ei75:produce an ei76:initiative that ``ei77:responds to the grave threat ei78:posed by weapons of mass destruction and their means of delivery.''
In Kosovo, where the Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic, is ei79:resisting the ei80:deployment of NATO-led troops, including 4,000 U.S. soldiers, Albright ei81:insisted that NATO ei82:was the best tool to ei83:enforce a peace ei84:settlement.
``We must ei105:be clear in ei86:explaining that a ei87:settlement without NATO-led ei88:enforcement ei89:is not acceptable because only NATO ei90:has the credibility and capability to ei91:make it ei92:work,'' she ei104:said. ``And we must ei96:be resolute in ei97:spelling out the ei98:consequences of intransigence,'' she ei99:added, ei100:referring to the threat of NATO air ei101:strikes against Milosevic if he does not ei102:agree to the ei103:deployment.
But in many ways, the day ei106:belonged to the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland, who in order to ei107:meet NATO's standards have ei110:had to ei108:cut the size of their Soviet-style militaries, ei109:organize civilian control of their armies and ei111:agree to ei112:buy NATO compatible equipment in the coming years.
It was the spiritual ei113:homecoming to the West that all three foreign ministers ei114:stressed.
``Poland forever ei115:returns where she has always ei116:belonged _ the free world,'' ei117:said Bronislaw Geremek, the foreign minister of Poland, who ei118:was a dissident during the Communist ei119:era.
Geremek ei120:said he had ei121:brought some appropriate mementoes from Poland to the Truman library, including a campaign poster from 1989 when the anti-communist Solidarity forces ei122:won against the Communists. The poster ei123:showed a picture of Gary Cooper from the film ``High Noon.''
``It ei124:helped us to ei125:win,'' Geremek ei223:said. ``For the people of Poland, high noon ei126:comes today.''
The Czech foreign minister, Jan Kavan, who ei127:lived in London from 1968, when the Soviets ei128:invaded Czechoslovakia, until 1989, ei129:said he had ei130:remained buoyant during his opposition ei131:work as an emigre by ei132:believing that communism would eventually ei133:fall. But he never ei134:dreamed, he ei135:said, that his country would ei136:become a member of NATO.
``ei137:Accession to NATO is a ei138:guarantee that we will never again ei139:become powerless victims of any foreign aggression,'' Kavan ei141:said.
Similarly, the Hungarian foreign minister, Janos Martonyi, who ei142:remembers the 1956 ei143:uprising as a 13-year-old, ei144:said that membership of NATO ei145:meant that Hungary was ei146:returning ``to her natural habitat.''
``It has ei147:been our manifest destiny to ei148:rejoin those with whom we ei149:share the same values, interests and goals,'' he ei150:said.
But Martonyi also ei151:emphasized that Hungary ei152:understood NATO membership ei153:carried with it obligations as well as privileges. ``We shall ei154:prove that new members can indeed ei155:add to the weight of the alliance,'' he ei156:said.
The location for Friday's ei157:ceremony was ei158:chosen by Albright, who as secretary of state ei159:is the depository of NATO's accession accords.
The secretary made the fairly unorthodox ei160:decision to ei161:choose a site outside Washington because she ei162:wanted the ei163:ceremony to ei164:resonate with the memories of President Truman, under whom NATO was ei165:founded. On April 4, 1949, on behalf of the United States, Truman's secretary of state, Dean Acheson, ei166:signed the Washington Treaty, which ei167:created NATO. Acheson is Albright's favorite predecessor, her aides ei168:said.
ei169:Formed in reaction to the threat of the Soviet Union under Stalin, NATO ei170:calls for the collective ei171:defense of its members and was ei172:brought into being with an original 12 members.
The alliance has ei173:expanded three times before, ei174:adding Greece and Turkey in 1952, West Germany in 1955 and Spain in 1982. But never before has NATO ei175:reached out to its former Eastern-bloc enemies.
The Clinton administration ei176:embarked on the ei177:expansion of NATO in 1993 after Clinton ei178:met in Washington with President Havel and Lech Walesa, who ei179:was then the president of Poland.
These ei180:conversations are ei181:remembered by Clinton's foreign policy team because they ei182:took place after the ei183:opening of the Holocaust Museum and because they ei184:involved two very different Central European leaders who ei185:brought the same message.
Their ei224:message was that NATO should be ei186:used as the mechanism to ei187:secure the democratic progress of their countries and at the same ei188:dissuade Russia from any more imperial designs.
The U.S. ambassador to Poland, Dan Fried, who ei190:was then on the National Security Council, ei189:said Friday that he ei191:remembered being ei192:asked to ei193:help ``ei194:turn this pious wish into a policy.''
In July 1997, at a ei195:summit in Madrid, Spain, the alliance ei196:announced it would ei197:accept Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Romania and Slovenia, which had ei198:tried hard to ei199:meet the standards, were ei200:turned away, at least for the time being.
One problem was how to ei201:deal with the Russians, who ei202:vacillated between outright hostility and accepting what ei203:looked like the inevitable. In early 1997, President Boris Yeltsin ei205:told President Clinton he could ei206:live with NATO ei207:expansion. But in order to accommodate the Russians, NATO ei208:created the NATO-Russia Council as a consultative body that ei209:formalized relations between Moscow and the alliance.
Poland has ei210:been sensitive to the ei211:reactions of Russia to its membership of NATO, and Geremek has ei212:gone out of his way to ei213:reassure the Russians. ``We ei214:want our membership of NATO to ei215:serve as a `catalyst' for Polish Russian co-operation,'' he ei216:said last year.
Even so, on the secretary of state's plane carrying Albright and the three foreign ministers to the ei217:ceremony Friday, the ministers were ei218:asked whether they could ever ei219:foresee Russia as a member of NATO.
There was a long ei220:pause among the three ministers. Then Martonyi ei221:replied: ``ei222:Silence is your answer.''

text:
With the ei1:finding of a buried rifle 11 days ago, the authorities in the Buffalo, N.Y., area ei2:say they have ei3:gathered enough evidence in the October ei4:slaying of Dr. Barnett Slepian to ei5:begin ei6:presenting a murder case to a state grand jury as early as next week.
A federal grand jury has already been ei7:addressing the ei8:slaying under laws that ei9:prohibit ei10:violence against providers of abortion. Slepian ei11:was the mainstay of Buffalo's only abortion clinic before he was ei12:shot to death last Oct. 23 at his home in suburban Amherst. But the ei13:decision by District Attorney Frank C. Clark to ei14:begin ei15:presenting evidence to a state grand jury ei16:suggests that he has ei17:amassed enough material to ei18:support a criminal indictment for homicide.
``We've ei19:gotten to the point where we ei20:know what we ei21:want to ei22:introduce before a grand jury,'' Clark ei23:said in a telephone ei24:interview Monday.
Although the authorities are not ei25:saying who the suspect ei26:is, all of the attention so far has ei27:fallen on James C. Kopp, a 44-year-old anti-abortion protester who had been ei28:traveling around the country from demonstration to demonstration for years.
Officially, Kopp is being ei29:sought as a ``material witness'' in the case.
Clark ei30:said it was easier to ei31:seek ei32:extradition of an indicted suspect from another state or a foreign country than of someone ei33:wanted as a material witness. For now, though, that would ei34:be a theoretical advantage since the authorities have ei35:admitted they ei36:have no idea where Kopp ei37:is.
Clark ei38:said there was ``no question'' that the ei39:finding of the rifle ei40:was important in his ei41:decision to ei42:seek an ei43:indictment. The rifle was ei44:discovered April 8 ei45:buried one foot below the ground, about 200 feet behind Slepian's house. It is ei46:undergoing testing at the FBI laboratory in Washington, but the authorities have ei47:said it ei48:resembles the kind of high-powered rifle ei49:used in the ei50:slaying.
Clark ei51:said other evidence that prosecutors might ei52:present ei53:includes a strand of human hair ei54:found at the wooded firing site that has a ``high likelihood'' of ei55:matching Kopp's hair and testimony from a jogger who ei56:spotted Kopp's car near Slepian's house at 6 a.m. ten days before the ei57:shooting. There also are videotapes of Kopp's car ei58:crossing the Canadian border around the days _ in 1994, 1995 and 1997 _ that three Canadian doctors who ei59:perform abortions were ei60:shot at. None of those doctors were ei61:killed.
If a suspect is ei62:caught and ei63:charged in both state and federal courts, a state trial would likely ei64:precede a federal one, ei65:giving the authorities two chances to ei66:prosecute. New York State double-jeopardy laws would ei67:make it difficult to ei68:prosecute a suspect who had been ei69:found not guilty at a federal trial.
U.S. Attorney Denise E. O'Donnell ei70:declined to ei71:discuss what federal charges were being ei72:pursued, but she ei73:said that in a case like this, potential charges would ei74:be abortion-related ei75:violence, the ei76:use of a firearm in an ei77:act of violence, ei78:crossing state lines to ei79:commit a crime, and, if the suspect's act was ei80:tied to an organization, violation of the so-called RICO statutes, which ei81:prohibit an organized criminal enterprise.
Slepian, 52, and the father of four boys, was ei82:shot to death at 10 p.m. as he ei83:stood ei84:chatting with his wife in the kitchen of their home in an affluent enclave in Amherst, which ei85:is the largest Buffalo suburb.
