text:
Federal law enforcement officials ei1:said Wednesday that they had ei2:concluded that James Kopp, an impassioned and nomadic opponent of abortion, ei3:fired the shots that ei4:killed a Buffalo, N.Y., abortion-clinic doctor last October.
Based on physical evidence _ including a rifle ei5:found in April month ei6:buried near the doctor's house and a ei8:match between fibers ei7:found near the murder and others ei9:found in Kopp's car _ officials ei10:said they had ei11:decided to ei12:issue a warrant for his arrest in the ei13:killing of Dr. Barnett Slepian.
Kopp, a fugitive, has until now been ei14:described only as a material witness and a nationwide warrant had been ei15:issued so that he could be ei16:held for ei17:questioning.
There ei18:was no official confirmation of the ei19:decision to ei20:upgrade the warrant, but Denise O'Donnell, the U.S. attorney for the Western District of New York in Buffalo, has ei21:scheduled a news ei22:conference Thursday to ei23:announce a ``major ei24:development'' in the Slepian murder investigation. Erie County District Attorney Frank Clark, Bernard Tolbert, the special FBI agent in charge of the Buffalo office, and other investigators will also ei25:be there.
Since there ei26:is no federal homicide statute as such, the federal officials ei27:said Kopp could be ei28:charged under the recent Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act, which ei29:provides for a ei30:sentence of up to life imprisonment for someone ei31:convicted of physical ei32:assaults or ei33:threats against abortion providers. If Kopp were also ei34:indicted and ei35:convicted on state murder charges, he could ei36:face the death penalty.
Slepian, a 52-year-old obstetrician and gynecologist who ei37:was the mainstay of Buffalo's only abortion clinic, was ei38:shot to death on the night of Oct. 23 as he ei39:stood in the kitchen of his home in suburban Amherst, N.Y. ei40:chatting with his wife and one of his four sons.
No weapon was ei41:recovered in the first police searches of the area around Slepian's home. But on April 8, investigators, ei42:wondering how the assailant could have ei43:emerged from the woods without ei44:fearing he would be ei45:seen ei46:carrying a rifle, ei47:searched the site of the ei48:shooting once more and ei49:unearthed a rifle ei50:buried one foot below ground 200 feet behind the Slepian home.
Clark, the Erie district attorney, ei51:said afterwards that investigators ei52:think the doctor's killer ei53:buried the rifle in the days before the ei55:shooting, ei56:unearthed the weapon to ei57:fire the fatal shots, then hurriedly ei58:reburied it and ei59:fled.
The 44-year-old Kopp, who in FBI photographs ei60:appears as gaunt and scruffily bearded and whose last known addresses ei61:were in Vermont and New Jersey, ei62:emerged as the focus of the investigation within two weeks of the ei63:slaying. A jogger ei64:observed Kopp's car at 6 a.m. near Slepian's home 10 days before the ei65:murder, and, ei66:curious why a stranger would be ei67:parked there so early, ei68:wrote down the license plate number.

text:
WASHINGTON _
A six-year-old boy who ei1:arrived on US shores as a motherless refugee and ei2:became a political symbol for anti-Castro exiles must be ei3:returned to his father in Cuba, immigration authorities ei4:ruled Wednesday.
Faced with the choice of keeping Elian Gonzalez with relatives in Miami, where the boy has been ei6:wooed with American toys and theme-park ei94:visits, or ei7:returning him to his apparently distraught father in Havana, the Immigration and Naturalization Service ei137:decided the boy should ei8:go home by Jan. 14, INS commissioner Doris Meissner ei9:told reporters.
``This little boy, who has been through so much, belongs with his father,'' Meissner ei11:told a news ei95:conference. ``The core issue here is the bond between the parent and the child.''
The ei97:decision was ei12:met with outrage by Cuban-Americans, who ei13:said the youngster will ei14:suffer under the repressive communist regime of Fidel Castro. Lawyers for the boy's family in Miami ei15:sent letters of protest to Attorney General Janet Reno and President Clinton and ei16:said they were ei17:prepared to ei18:file a court ei100:appeal if Reno and Clinton ei19:spurn the Gonzalez family.
Anti-Castro demonstrators ei138:thronged the street near the local INS office in Miami Wednesday, ei20:demanding that Elian be ei21:allowed to ei22:stay.
``Today is a sad day for the US Constitution . . . and for the hopes and dreams of Elian's mother Elizabeth,'' who ei139:died with nine other adults when their boat ei23:sank as they ei24:attempted to ei25:reach Florida, ei26:said Roger Bernstein, ei27:representing the Miami Gonzalez family.
``Nobody ei28:wants the boy to be ei140:separated from his father,'' ei29:said Ninoska Perez of the Miami-based Cuban-American National Foundation. ``But that little boy, by ei31:surviving two days on an inner tube, has ei141:earned the right to ei32:stay here in freedom.''
In Havana, the government ei33:gave a guarded first ei105:response to the INS ei106:ruling, ei107:warning against ``excessive optimism'' and ei35:predicting ``the Cuban-American mafia and the extreme right in the U.S. Congress'' would still ei36:put up a ei109:fight to ei37:keep the boy.
Meissner ei38:said the INS ei110:decision was made after two lengthy ei111:interviews with the boy's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, a hotel worker in Cardenas, Cuba, who Meissner ei40:said is anxious to have Elian ei41:returned to him.
Since the boy is so young, Meissner ei42:said, the natural father has the right to ei43:speak for Elian.
There is ``no information'' that Gonzalez, who was ei44:divorced from Elian's mother, is an unfit father, nor that he has been ei142:coerced by the Castro regime into ei45:pleading for his son's ei112:return, Meissner ei46:said.
Spencer Eig, an attorney for the Gonzalez family in Miami, ei47:said Meissner's assumptions were ``unconstitutional and untrue.''
``Elian cannot ei143:apply for asylum from persecution by the Fidel Castro government,'' Eig complained. ``If only his father, who is under the control of the Fidel Castro regime, can ei48:do it for him . . . that is deeply unfair and untrue.''
Meissner ei49:gave no reason for the Jan. 14 deadline, and it is still unclear how Elian would be ei50:transported back to Cuba if the Gonzalez family's ei116:appeals are unsuccessful.
The INS ei51:offered three options: that Gonzalez ei52:come to ei53:pick up his son, that the family in Miami ei117:take him to Cuba, or that a ``third party'' ei118:escort the child to his homeland.
Gonzalez _ perhaps under duress from the Castro regime _ has ei54:indicated he does not ei55:want to ei56:travel to Miami, and there is ``no way'' the Miami Gonzalezes will ei57:assist in ei58:sending Elian back to Cuba, Perez ei59:said.
Having a third party ei144:escort Elian ei60:frees the INS from the politically uncomfortable spectacle of having to ei61:do the task itself. The Cuban-American lobby is a locally powerful political force few politicians ei62:want to ei63:provoke.
Clinton has ei64:sought to distance himself from the ei122:controversy from the ei123:start. ``I ei65:told you when we ei66:started this I would ei67:do my best to ei68:keep the ei124:decision out of politics,'' Clinton ei69:told reporters in the Rose Garden Wednesday. ``We have done that.''
But if Elian is ei70:forced to ei71:go back to Cuba, ``the Clinton-Gore administration, specifically (Vice President) Al Gore, will ei72:pay a high price in terms of votes in Florida,'' Perez ei73:said.
Cuba experts and child custody lawyers ei74:said the INS ei129:ruling was appropriate under the law.
``It's high time'' the boy was ei75:sent back to his birthplace, ei76:said Wayne Smith, a former Clinton administration adviser on Cuba. ``This was a simple child custody case.''
``Every state court and every family court in the United States would ei133:award custody to a surviving parent rather than a distant relative who ei78:lives a more prosperous life,'' ei79:said David Abraham, a professor at Miami Law School and expert in custody law.
``We may have the Disneylands and the Universal Studios and all the things that were ei80:dangled before the little boy's eyes,'' Abraham added. ``But that's his home.''
With the political implications so strong, it's unlikely the case of Elian Gonzalez will be ei81:closed quickly, ei82:said Richard Nuccio, a former Clinton administration Cuba adviser.
``With two members of Congress ei83:representing Elian's family's constituency, I don't ei85:see how Elian could be ei86:returned by the federal government without it ei87:going through the court system,'' Nuccio ei88:said.

text:
The New York Times ei1:says in an editorial on Thursday, Jan. 6: &QL;
The U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service ei2:made a reasonable ei47:decision Wednesday in ei48:ruling that Elian Gonzalez, the 6-year-old boy who ei3:survived an ill-fated migrant smuggling ei50:trip across the Florida Straits, should be ei72:reunited with his father back in Cuba. The ei51:decision will ei5:inflame anti-Castro Cubans in Miami, but Doris Meissner, the INS commissioner, ei6:made it clear that the service had ei7:followed established policy in the case. Moreover, by ei9:setting a Jan. 14 ei52:return date, the immigration service ei10:allowed Elian's American relatives time to ei11:test the ei54:ruling in court.
Elian was one of 13 Cubans who were ei12:trying to ei13:cross from Cuba to Florida six weeks ago on a 17-foot aluminum powerboat when it ei14:capsized. Ten of those on board ei73:died, including his mother and stepfather. The boy ei16:clung to an inner tube for two days and was ei17:plucked from the Atlantic on Thanksgiving Day and ei18:brought ashore. He was immediately ei19:released into the custody of relatives in Miami _ and just as quickly ei20:embraced as a pawn in the poisonous estrangement between Fidel Castro's regime and its opponents in exile.
This page has ei21:argued from the ei59:start that Elian not be ei22:denied due process because of his youth, and the INS ei23:appears to have ei24:moved carefully. Elian's great-uncle and other American relatives were ei25:allowed to ei26:make their case that he should have a life in Miami. The boy's ei27:divorced father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, was also ei28:interviewed and ei74:satisfied the agency that he had a close and involved relationship with his son. The mother's parents also ei29:argued for a ei61:return to Cuba. The INS ei75:decided that under their prevailing policies, Gonzalez ei30:met the test that calls for custody ei32:reverting to the sole surviving parent in such cases.
``This little boy, who has been through so much, belongs with his father,'' Meissner ei35:said Wednesday, ei76:adding that ``the unique relationship between parent and child and family reunification has long been a cornerstone of both American immigration law and INS practice.'' The White House quickly ei36:announced support for the ei68:decision.
It is unclear how the political side of this affair will ei37:play out. Elian's relatives in Miami have ei38:indicated they ei39:plan to ei40:appeal, as is their right. Some of their more militant supporters in Miami, ei77:decrying the prospect that the boy will be ei41:used as a ``trophy'' by Castro, have ei42:indicated they may ei43:try to ei44:disrupt efforts to ei78:reunite Elian with his father. That would be ei45:treating the boy as a trophy in a diplomatic ei70:struggle that predates his ei71:birth by decades.

text:
ATLANTA _
Good for Attorney General Janet Reno for the sensible opinion she ei1:rendered in the case of Elian Gonzalez. Some semblance of constitutional order was necessary after a Miami judge ei2:turned legal logic on its head in an effort to ei66:route to her family court his Florida relatives' ei40:appeal to ei4:keep the 6-year-old in the United States.
Immigration, after all, is strictly a federal matter. If the Immigration and Naturalization Service ei41:order that Elian must be ei5:returned to his father in Cuba is to be ei6:contested, Reno ei7:ruled correctly that the only proper venue is federal court, not state or local.
If and when the relatives' ei42:appeal ei9:goes to federal court, chances of a favorable ei43:ruling are slim. First of all, the INS already has ei10:taken the position the only person who can ei11:petition for U.S. asylum for Elian is his father, which he is not about to ei12:do. Moreover, immigration law ei13:provides that asylum can only be ei14:granted where there is an imminent threat of ei67:torture or ei68:persecution in the petitioner's homeland, which nobody ei16:expects in Elian's case.
It's not enough to ei17:argue Elian may ei18:suffer ei69:privation or ei70:oppression in Fidel Castro's ei19:failed Communist state. The INS routinely ei20:sends prospective immigrants back to countries where poverty and tyranny are worse than in Cuba.
What matters most is that Elian, after ei21:losing his mother and stepfather in a disastrous sea ei54:voyage to the United States last November, ei22:needs the love and care of surviving family members who've known him all his life _ his father and both sets of grandparents in Cuba. True, they can't ei25:give him all the material things his Miami benefactors can, but there are intangibles in close family bonds that are more valuable than bicycles and ei59:trips to Disney World.
The next order of business for the Justice Department and the INS is to ei26:resolve Elian's case promptly. They mustn't ei71:countenance any delays by lawyers for his Miami relatives. He has been ei72:separated from his loved ones too long.
Besides, the longer his ei62:return is ei28:put off, the greater the chance of ei63:interference by calculating congressmen ei30:playing to the anti-Castro lobby. Already one grandstanding Indiana Republican has ei73:subpoenaed Elian to testify before a House panel, and others in the Senate are ei31:preparing to ei32:vote the boy U.S. citizenship. Both ei64:ploys are ei33:intended to ei34:thwart his ei65:reunion with his father.
Congress reconvenes Jan. 24. The Justice Department and the INS mustn't ei35:allow the opportunists of Capitol Hill to ei36:get their hooks into Elian.

MIAMI _
The angry crowd ei1:rushed at Manuel Gonzalez as he ei2:stepped out of Miami's federal courthouse, ei3:shaking fists at him and ei189:shouting in Spanish, ``communista'' and ``traitor.''
But the great-uncle of 6-year-old ei130:shipwreck survivor rafter Elian Gonzalez only ei4:ducked his head and ei5:walked faster.
In a drama that has ei190:divided his once close-knit family and may finally be ei7:resolved in a court ei132:hearing the week of March 6, Manuel Gonzalez, 59, a soft-spoken bus mechanic, has remained largely out of the glare of television lights.
Until this week.
He was ei10:thrust into the middle of the ei191:swirling Gonzalez family saga when Elian's father, Juan Miguel, ei11:sent a letter to U.S. Attorney Janet Reno ei12:asking that his son be ei13:moved to Manuel Gonzalez's home.
Alone among his two brothers and two sisters who have ei14:fled Cuba for Miami, Manuel Gonzalez ei15:believes Elian should ei16:go back to Cuba to ei17:live with his father.
Reno ei18:denied the ei134:request, but Manuel Gonzalez didn't ei192:back down.
In a town where ei19:expressing even the slightest approval for Cuban President Fidel Castro can ei20:prompt threats of physical harm, Manuel Gonzalez ei21:filed a motion in federal court ei22:asking for custody of Elian so that he could ei23:help ei193:reunite the boy with his father in Cuba.
It was a move that many ei24:see as courageous and principled, but others fear may be foolhardy.
``I have ei26:lost a son,'' Gonzalez ei27:told reporters later, ei28:referring to his own son's ei141:death due to cancer. ``I am ei29:supporting Juan Miguel because I ei30:know what it is to ei31:lose a son. Elian should be with his father.''
His sincerity didn't ei143:stop the talk on Little Havana's streets or on Miami's ubiquitous Spanish-language radio stations, which ei32:buzzed with callers ei194:lambasting Gonzalez for ei33:playing into the hands of a tyrant.
A day after he was ei195:hounded on the steps of the federal courthouse, Manuel Gonzalez wouldn't ei34:come to the door of his modest home in Miami's Little Havana.
``He must ei35:go to ei36:work,'' ei37:said his daughter, Rosa, who ei38:said Gonzalez would ei39:prefer not to ei40:talk about the issue. ``There has been a lot of pressure, and he feels this is a family affair.''
After weeks of high-profile public ei147:sparring _ with charges of ei149:abuse, ei42:spying and ei150:treachery ei43:flying back and forth across the Florida Straits _ it would ei44:seem the chances are slim that the Gonzalez family could ever ei196:heal the wounds ei45:created by the Elian saga.
But the family has ei46:overcome steep obstacles before. Long before Elian ei152:thrust them into the unrelenting glare of the international spotlight, the Gonzalez clan was a typical example of the ei154:conflicts and painful ei155:separations ei47:wrought by the Cuban ei156:revolution.
Of the nine brothers and sisters of Manuel's generation, five have ei48:come to Miami, while three remain in Cuba and one has ei50:passed away.
According to press ei158:reports, Caridad Gonzalez, the oldest sister, was the first to ei52:come to the United States, ei53:arriving in 1966. Her brother Delfin, who was ei54:imprisoned as an anti-Castro activist in the 1960s, ei55:followed in 1979. Then ei56:came another sister, Georgina, in 1983, ei57:followed by Manuel and Lazaro in 1984.
Of those who ei58:stayed in Cuba, Juan Miguel's father, Juan Gonzalez, ei59:seems the most closely allied with the Cuban government. He ei60:worked as a police officer in a Cuban ministry, a position that probably ei61:helped his son _ Elian's father _ ei62:get a job in the Communist island's increasingly lucrative tourism industry.
The family's ei161:experience is like that of thousands of others now split between Miami and Cuba, ei63:said Damien Fernandez, a Cuban-American political scientist at Florida International University.
``Cubans value their families above almost anything, but the post-1959 politics have ei64:managed to ei65:split thousands of families apart,'' he ei66:said.
For decades, Cuban Americans in Miami were largely ei67:cut off from the families they ei68:left behind. Labeled ``worms'' and ``traitors'' by Castro, many weren't able to ei69:speak to _ much less ei164:visit _ their relatives for years.
The situation ei70:began to ei71:relax in the early 1990s, with the ei166:crisis ei72:triggered by the ei167:end of the former Soviet Union's subsidies. In desperate need of hard currency, Castro ei73:relaxed travel restrictions and ei74:allowed Cubans to have U.S. dollars, ei75:triggering a trickle of cash from Miami that soon ei77:became a flood.
By some estimates, the 700,000 Cubans living in South Florida _ and elsewhere in the United States _ ei79:send $1 billion a year in remittances back to their families on the island.
``The Miami families have ei80:become a lifeline, and since 1990 there has been a great trend toward ei174:reconciliation,'' ei81:said Florida International's Fernandez. ``Although many families are still divided by politics, they have ei82:learned to ei83:forgive and ei84:forget and ei85:find common ground.''
Prior to Elian, the Gonzalez family apparently was no different. The branches of the family regularly ei86:talked by telephone and the Miami relatives ei87:went back to Cuba for several family ei88:reunions.
But Elian's case has ei89:broken down the family's fragile truce, with their political differences ei90:exacerbated by the inflammatory rhetoric ei91:flying between Castro's government and exile extremists in Miami.
After making his opinions known, Manuel Gonzalez reportedly was ei94:ostracized by his Miami kin, especially Lazaro, who has been ei95:keeping Elian and who has ei96:gone to court to ei98:try to ei99:keep the boy here.
But there has been at least one ei178:attempt at a ei179:resolution. The day before last Tuesday's federal court ei180:hearing, Manuel ei100:went to Lazaro's home to ei101:try to ei102:work out their differences. Neither side would ei103:say what ei104:happened, but when Manuel ei105:returned to his house, he was so upset he ei106:felt heart palpitations and was ei107:taken to a hospital.
He was soon ei108:released and ei109:appeared to be reasonably healthy when he ei110:appeared in court the next morning. But while Cuban exiles outside the courthouse ei111:cheered Lazaro and his family, their angry taunts ei112:seemed to ei113:shock Manuel.
His lawyer, however, ei114:insists he will ei115:continue to ei116:stand up for what he ei117:thinks is right.
``He's a strong man,'' ei118:said Jeffrey Leving. ``He won't ei119:let anyone ei120:intimidate him from ei121:doing what is in Elian's best interests.''
To his credit, Lazaro Gonzalez has ei122:issued a statement ei123:asking Miami's exiles to ei124:respect his brother's opinions.
Manuel Gonzalez has ei125:told reporters that he ei126:believes his family will ei127:recover _ at least partially _ from the divisions Elian's case has ei128:brought.
``The wounds of the problem will ei197:heal,'' he ei129:told the Los Angeles Times newspaper. ``But the scars will always be there.''

Once Gonzalez ei10:comes to the United States _ it would be preferable if he ei11:went to Miami rather than to Washington _ only the most obdurate foes of Castro can ei12:argue that Elian should not be ei89:reunited with him. The Clinton administration's wisdom in ei1:returning Elian Gonzalez to his father was ei2:confirmed over the weekend decision of his Miami relatives and their Republican allies to further politicize what ought to be a straightforward child-custody case. Elian is finally ei4:getting time to ei63:reconnect with his father in a quiet, neutral setting where he is no longer a metaphor for the ei44:war between the Cubans.
A few miles from his temporary home at Andrews Air Force Base, Senator Bob Smith of New Hampshire, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, both Republicans, and the relatives were ei5:treating the ei45:raid to ei6:return Elian as though it were a Nazi SS ei46:operation. Yet federal agents had a warrant, were ei7:enforcing US law, and ei8:entered the house with the proper force to ei9:ensure minimal ei47:resistance and ei48:injury. It was a model of efficient law enforcement, guided by due process.
The ei51:raid was necessary because the Gonzalez relatives in Miami, ei10:refusing to ei11:return the boy, made him into a symbol of resistance to Fidel Castro. Elian ei13:printed his name on an application for asylum and was ei14:put in front of a video camera to ei15:say that he did not ei16:want to ei17:go back to Cuba. The relatives ei18:treated the boy like a political prop.
As did Castro, a master manipulator of public opinion in Cuba. Had the relatives ei20:allowed Elian to ei21:return to Cuba, they would have ei22:denied the dictator an opportunity to ei64:reenergize support for his regime.
Juan Miguel Gonzalez apparently is a Castro supporter, but that should not ei65:disqualify him from being ei66:reunited with his child. Ever since he first ei23:learned that Elian was in Florida last November, he has been persistent in ei24:seeking the boy's ei57:return.
Elian has ei25:developed great affection for the Miami relatives. It would be ideal if they could have ei26:returned him to his father yet ei27:stayed in contact while their ei60:appeal was pending in court. Negotiations ei28:failed, however, because they ei29:insisted on ei30:taking the place of the father, rather than being ei31:treated as concerned, yet distant, relatives.
Juan and Elian Gonzalez will remain in the United States pending the ei61:appeal. The father can remain here, but he can also ei35:return to Cuba if he ei36:wishes. Like any other 6-year-old in the care of a loving parent, Elian should ei38:go wherever that parent ei39:wants.
